title: Quiz: FQE February 2021 - Community Health
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Clinical Medicine & Surgery - Community Health (February 2021)

questions.question: With regards to occupational health and safety, which of the following is a type of pneumoconiosis?
questions.explanation: Pneumoconiosis is a group of interstitial lung diseases caused by the inhalation of mineral dusts. Silicosis is caused by inhaling crystalline silica dust.
questions.hint: It is caused by silica dust.

questions.question: In regards to ergonomic hazards, which statement is correct?

options.text: Not wearing PPEs is a risk
It involves risk of awkward movement
Poor lighting and ventilation is a risk factor
It is the same as physical hazard

questions.explanation: Ergonomic hazards relate to how the body interacts with the work environment, such as repetitive strain, awkward postures, or improper lifting.
questions.hint: Think about body mechanics and movement.

questions.question: Examples of international notifiable diseases include the following, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: International notifiable diseases (under IHR) are those that constitute a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (e.g., Yellow Fever, Plague, Cholera, Ebola). Leprosy is a chronic disease, not an acute emergency.
questions.hint: Which disease is chronic and slow-moving, unlike the acute outbreaks listed?

questions.question: The most hygienic method of disposing of the body of a Covid-19 victim is:
questions.explanation: Cremation is considered the most hygienic method as high temperatures completely destroy all pathogens.
questions.hint: This method uses high heat to destroy pathogens.

questions.question: Water washed diseases include:
questions.explanation: Water-washed diseases are caused by lack of water for hygiene (e.g., Trachoma). (Note: Options are mixed, but D contains Trachoma which is the classic example).
questions.hint: Look for the option containing Trachoma.

questions.question: Concerning water treatment, the next phase after aeration is:
questions.explanation: The typical sequence is Screening -> Aeration -> Coagulation/Flocculation -> Sedimentation -> Filtration -> Disinfection.
questions.hint: After removing gases, we add chemicals to make particles clump together.

questions.question: Concerning communicable disease transmission, which statement is correct?

options.text: Mosquitoes transmit yellow fever and filariasis
Sand flies transmit onchocerciasis and malaria
Ticks transmit dengue and relapsing fever
Fleas transmit relapsing and dengue fever

questions.explanation: Mosquitoes transmit Malaria, Yellow Fever, Dengue, and Filariasis. Sandflies transmit Kala-azar. Ticks transmit Relapsing fever. Fleas transmit Plague.
questions.hint: Aedes and Culex are types of this vector.

questions.question: About clinical waste from the hospital:

options.text: Black is for sharps and general wastes
Safety box is for waste with blood stains

questions.explanation: Yellow color coding is for infectious waste. Safety boxes are specifically for sharps.
questions.hint: The standard color for infectious material.

questions.question: Human fascioliasis arises from consumption of vegetables contaminated by:
questions.explanation: Fasciola eggs are passed in faeces (sheep/cattle/human), hatch in water, infect snails, and encyst on plants like watercress.
questions.hint: The eggs are excreted in stool.

questions.question: Cyst of Echinococcus granulosus is usually found in uncooked vegetables contaminated by excreta of:
questions.explanation: Dogs are the definitive host for Echinococcus granulosus (Hydatid disease) and shed eggs in their feces.
questions.hint: Man's best friend is the definitive host here.

questions.question: Regarding elements of Primary Health Care (PHC), which statement implies the broad goal?

options.text: It was developed in Alma Atta conference in 1998
They are ten in number where Kenya added four
Education that is tertiary level and secondary is a key element
It helps in improving the living standards only for the community

questions.explanation: This is an exclusion question. Alma Ata was 1978 (A false). Original elements were 8 (B false). Education focuses on health problems, not tertiary (C false). D is the most plausible intended answer regarding community development.
questions.hint: Alma Ata was in 1978, not 1998.

questions.question: In the four tiers of health, primary health care involves:

options.text: Health centers and sub county hospitals
County referral hospital and community level

questions.explanation: Tier 2 (Primary Care) consists of Dispensaries and Health Centers. Tier 1 is Community.
questions.hint: Think of the first facilities a patient visits.

questions.question: The vector involved in the transmission of Trachoma is:
questions.explanation: The House Fly (Musca domestica) acts as a mechanical vector carrying Chlamydia trachomatis from eye to eye.
questions.hint: The common house fly.

questions.question: A high BOD (Biological Oxygen Demand) indicates:
questions.explanation: High BOD means there is a lot of organic waste for bacteria to eat, depleting oxygen. It indicates high pollution.
questions.hint: High demand for oxygen means lots of bacteria are working hard to eat waste.

questions.question: Human papilloma virus (HPV) is a vaccine currently administered by MOH to girls aged?
questions.explanation: The HPV vaccine target age for the initial rollout in Kenya was 10 years (girls).
questions.hint: Before sexual debut, usually class 4 or 5.

questions.question: Total doses administered for hepatitis B vaccine (standard adult schedule or implied context):
questions.explanation: Standard Hep B is 3 doses. However, based on the source exam key/context which marked 'C' (Two doses), we include this option. Note: Standard practice is 3 doses. This question may refer to specific rotavirus doses or have a typo.
questions.hint: The exam paper marked 'Two doses' though 3 is standard practice.

questions.question: In regards to rabies:

options.text: It is a water borne disease

questions.explanation: Rabies is a viral zoonosis transmitted from animals to humans.
questions.hint: It comes from animal bites.

questions.question: The presence of high coliform counts in water indicate:
questions.explanation: Coliform bacteria inhabit the intestines of warm-blooded animals and indicate fecal contamination.
questions.hint: Coliforms come from the colon (feces).

questions.question: Aluminum sulphate is usually added at which level of water treatment?
questions.explanation: Alum is a coagulant used to destabilize particles.
questions.hint: It makes the dirt clump together (Coagulation).

questions.question: The most effective way to prevent water washed diseases is:

options.text: Provision of sufficient amount of clean water

questions.explanation: Water-washed diseases are caused by lack of water quantity for hygiene. Quantity is more critical than quality here.
questions.hint: You need ENOUGH water to wash.

questions.question: Among the following, which one is an element of primary health care?
questions.explanation: Immunization is one of the specific 8 core elements defined at Alma Ata.
questions.hint: One of the specific 'Big 8' elements.

questions.question: Aedes egyptae is a causative agent (vector) of:
questions.explanation: Aedes aegypti transmits Yellow Fever and Dengue. Yellow Fever is the classic answer.
questions.hint: It transmits a disease causing jaundice.

questions.question: Signs of microbial spoilage of food include:
questions.explanation: Sliminess and bad odors are signs of bacterial/fungal activity.
questions.hint: It feels slippery or sticky.

questions.question: Products which contain hydrogen cyanide poisoning:

options.text: Tomatoes which are brownish in colour
Potatoes which are greenish in colour

questions.explanation: Cassava contains cyanogenic glycosides.
questions.hint: A root tuber common in many parts of Africa.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases can be transmitted through direct contact?
questions.explanation: Hepatitis B is transmitted via direct contact with infected blood/fluids.
questions.hint: It is blood-borne and sexually transmitted.

questions.question: Among the non-communicable diseases, which one is the leading cause of mortality worldwide?
questions.explanation: Cardiovascular diseases (Heart disease/Stroke) are the #1 killers globally.
questions.hint: Diseases of the heart and blood vessels.

questions.question: Concerning cancer, which statement is FALSE?

options.text: Viruses can be a causative agent
Prostate cancer is common in males above 60 years
Cancer of the cervix can be prevented with human papilloma vaccine

questions.explanation: Most cancers (90-95%) are sporadic (environmental/lifestyle), NOT hereditary.
questions.hint: Is cancer mostly genetic or environmental?

questions.question: The following are sources of demographic data EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Level of economy is a characteristic/indicator, not a method of collecting data.
questions.hint: Which one is a financial status, not a data collection method?

questions.question: Which is NOT a factor responsible for change in population (direct component)?
questions.explanation: Births (Fertility), Deaths (Mortality), and Migration are the 3 direct components. Age groups are a structure.
questions.hint: Which one is a structural category, not an event?

questions.question: A factor which does not influence the fertility rate:
questions.explanation: Climate has negligible direct influence compared to social factors like marriage age and religion.
questions.hint: The weather doesn't change how many babies people have.

questions.question: The following are details contained in a medical death certificate EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: The medical certificate focuses on the cause of death and deceased's ID. Next of kin is usually on the burial permit/notification, not the medical cause certification itself.
questions.hint: The certificate is about the DEAD person and the CAUSE.

questions.question: An example of a biological hazard in a work place:
questions.explanation: Bacteria are living organisms (Biological). The others are Physical hazards.
questions.hint: It is a living organism.

questions.question: Which one is NOT an example of descriptive study in epidemiology?
questions.explanation: Clinical experimental studies are Interventional/Experimental, not Descriptive.
questions.hint: This involves doing an experiment, not just describing.

questions.question: An example of probability sample technique in research is:
questions.explanation: Cluster sampling involves random selection of groups.
questions.hint: It is a random method.

questions.question: Which is NOT a component of the epidemiological triad?
questions.explanation: The Triad is Agent, Host, and Environment. Time is a variable, but not a vertex of the triangle (though often added in the center). Reservoir is part of the chain of infection. In MCQs, Time or Reservoir are common distractors.
questions.hint: The triangle has three corners: Agent, Host, Environment.

questions.question: The following are agent characteristics for disease causation EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Resistance is typically a HOST characteristic (immunity) or an acquired trait, not a primary intrinsic pathogenicity factor like Virulence.
questions.hint: This usually refers to the Host's ability to fight back.

questions.question: Concerning the term pandemic, which is true?

options.text: Disease is localized in the community

questions.explanation: AIDS is a classic example of a pandemic (global spread).
questions.hint: It spreads across the whole world.

questions.question: Incidence of a disease means:

options.text: Old + new cases of a disease

questions.explanation: Incidence counts NEW cases. Prevalence counts Old + New.
questions.hint: Think 'Incidence' = 'Incoming' (New).

questions.question: Which one is not an example of observational study?
questions.explanation: Clinical trials are experimental, not observational.
questions.hint: The researcher interferes/treats the patients.

questions.question: Which statement is true concerning MDR tuberculosis?
questions.explanation: MDR-TB is resistance to at least Isoniazid and Rifampicin.
questions.hint: Resistance to the two most powerful first-line drugs.

questions.question: Match the epidemiological term with its definition:

pairs.right: Cases in excess of normal expectancy
Constant presence in a specific area

questions.explanation: Epidemic (Outbreak), Endemic (Native/Constant), Pandemic (Global), Morbidity (Illness).
questions.hint: Match the scope of the disease spread.

questions.question: Select the methods of PROBABILITY sampling:
questions.explanation: Probability sampling uses random selection.
questions.hint: Methods where everyone has an equal chance of being picked.

questions.question: Identify the 5 elements of Primary Health Care (PHC) from the list:
questions.explanation: PHC elements are the basic essential services.
questions.hint: Think Alma Ata declaration.

questions.question: Match the class of workplace hazard to its example:
questions.explanation: Hazards are classified by their nature (Energy, Substance, Organism, Body, Mind).
questions.hint: Match the type to the agent.

questions.question: Differentiate between Emerging and Re-emerging diseases. Which are EMERGING?
questions.explanation: Emerging are new (Covid, Ebola, HIV). Re-emerging are old ones coming back (TB, Malaria).
questions.hint: New diseases vs Old ones returning.

questions.question: Arrange the phases of the Disaster Management Cycle:
questions.explanation: Prevent -> Plan -> React -> Rebuild.
questions.hint: Logical order of handling a disaster.

questions.question: Select causes and risk factors for drug abuse:
questions.explanation: Factors include pressure, stress, access, and poor guidance.
questions.hint: Negative social factors.

questions.question: Select the key features of a Clinical Trial:
questions.explanation: Experiments need randomization, controls, and active intervention.
questions.hint: Scientific experiment features.

questions.question: Select the three major methods of preventing infectious diseases:

richContent.content: Strategies: Break the chain of transmission.

questions.explanation: Vaccines, Clean Water/Hygiene, and controlling vectors are the pillars of infectious disease control.
questions.hint: The big three public health interventions.
